Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  params = NULL,
  seed = lifecycle::deprecated(),
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "output", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

API key to use for authentication.

You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable. The best place to set this is in .Renviron, which you can easily edit by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

params

Common model parameters, usually created by params().

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call. Combined with the body object generated by ellmer with modifyList().

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_anthropic(), chat_aws_bedrock(), chat_azure_openai(), chat_cloudflare(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_github(), chat_google_gemini(), chat_groq(), chat_huggingface(), chat_mistral(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Origin and Structure**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: A traditional data frame is a basic data structure 
#> in R, derived from base R. It is designed to store tabular data with 
#> rows and columns, similar to a table in a database or an Excel 
#> spreadsheet.
#>   - *Tibble*: Tibbles are part of the `tibble` or `tidyverse` package 
#> in R and are an enhanced version of data frames. They provide a modern
#> approach to data manipulation with a focus on improved usability.
#> 
#> - **Printing and Display**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: By default, data frames print all rows and columns, 
#> which can be overwhelming for large datasets. They may also alter 
#> column names to make them syntactically valid by adding quotes.
#>   - *Tibble*: Tibbles offer a more user-friendly print method, 
#> displaying only the first 10 rows and fitting columns to the available
#> console width, thereby not overwhelming the user. Column names are 
#> preserved, even if they are not syntactically valid.
#> 
#> - **Column Types**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: Converts strings to factors by default, which can be
#> inconvenient if text data needs to be kept as character vectors.
#>   - *Tibble*: Does not automatically convert strings to factors, 
#> treating them as character vectors unless explicitly defined 
#> otherwise.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting and Indexing**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: Supports both row and column indexing; column 
#> indexing by default supports partial name matching, which can 
#> occasionally lead to unexpected results.
#>   - *Tibble*: Requires exact column names for indexing, which reduces 
#> the risk of errors from partial matching and enhances code 
#> readability.
#> 
#> - **Row Names**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: Supports row names, which can sometimes lead to 
#> inefficiencies and complexities when row names are used for indexing 
#> or data manipulation.
#>   - *Tibble*: Does not support row names to keep the data structure 
#> simpler and to encourage the use of explicit columns for identifiers 
#> instead.
#> 
#> - **Nesting**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: Not typically designed for nesting lists or other 
#> complex structures within columns.
#>   - *Tibble*: Allows for cleaner nesting of lists or even other 
#> tibbles within columns, providing more flexibility for complex data 
#> structures.
#> 
#> - **Error Handling**:  
#>   - *Data Frame*: Less strict in error reporting, which can 
#> occasionally lead to subtle bugs when data types and structures are 
#> mishandled.
#>   - *Tibble*: Generally more rigorous in error reporting and checking,
#> alerting users to potential issues earlier in the data manipulation 
#> process.
#> 
#> Tibbles are designed to improve user experience, particularly in 
#> interactive analyses, by addressing some of the limitations inherent 
#> in traditional data frames.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statisticians")
#> Sure, here are three light-hearted jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1. Why don't statisticians play hide and seek?
#>    - Because good luck hiding when they always assume you're normally 
#> distributed!
#> 
#> 2. A statistician is someone who can have his head in an oven and his 
#> feet in a freezer and say that on average he feels fine.
#> 
#> 3. How do you know a statistician is reading a book?
#>    - He starts at the end and looks for the p-value!
#> 
#> I hope these bring a smile to your face!
